<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The information contained in this Annual Report is current at November 17, 2006 except where a different date is specified.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Unless otherwise specified, all monetary amounts are expressed in Canadian dollars.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Financial information is presented in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in Canada. Differences between accounting principles generally accepted in Canada and in the United States, as applicable to our company, are set forth in Note 15 to the accompanying consolidated financial statements.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	Forward-Looking Statements

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:13.333PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	This report contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of the United States Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 concerning our exploration, operations, planned acquisitions and other matters. &nbsp;These statements relate to analyses and other information that are based on forecasts of future results, estimates of amounts not yet determinable and assumptions of management.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:13.333PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Statements concerning mineral resource estimates may also be deemed to constitute forward-looking statements to the extent that they involve estimates of the mineralization that will be encountered if the property is developed, and based on certain assumptions that the mineral deposit can be economically exploited. &nbsp;Any statements that express or involve discussions with respect to predictions, expectations, beliefs, plans, projections, objectives, assumptions or future events or performance (often, but not always, using words or phrases such as &#147;expects&#148; or &#147;does not expect&#148;, &#147;is expected&#148;, &#147;anticipates&#148; or &#147;does not anticipate&#148;, &#147;plans&#148;, &#147;estimates&#148; or &#147;intends&#148;, or stating that certain actions, events or results &#147;may&#148;, &#147;could&#148;, &#147;would&#148;, &#147;might&#148; or &#147;will&#148; be taken, occur or be achieved) are not statements of historical fact and may be &#147;forward-looking statements.&#148; &nbsp;Forward-looking statements are subject to a variety of risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual events or results to differ from those reflected in the forward-looking statements, including, without limitation:
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN BOLD" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN BOLD">
<B>
	CAUTIONARY NOTE TO UNITED STATES READERS - DIFFERENCES REGARDING THE DEFINITIONS OF RESOURCE AND RESERVE ESTIMATES IN THE UNITED STATES AND CANADA
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE:13.333PX" CELLSPACING=0>
<TR>
<TD WIDTH=126.533>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH=547.867>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN=TOP WIDTH=126.533>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Mineral Reserve
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN=TOP WIDTH=547.867>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT:10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The definitions of &#147;mineral reserves&#148;, &#147;proven mineral reserves&#148; and &#147;probable mineral reserves,&#148; as used in this report, are Canadian mining terms as defined in accordance with
<I>
	National Instrument 43-101 - Standards of Disclosure for Mineral Projects
</I>
	under the guidelines set out in the Canadian Institute of Mining, Metallurgy and Petroleum (the &#147;CIM&#148;) Standards on Mineral Resources and Mineral Reserves Definitions and guidelines adopted by the CIM Council on August 20, 2000. CIM standards differ from the standards in the United States.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT:10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Under United States standards, a &#147;mineral reserve&#148; is defined as a part of a mineral deposit which could be economically and legally extracted or produced at the time the mineral reserve determination is made, where:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:29.133PX; PADDING-RIGHT:10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&#147;reserve&#148; means that part of a mineral deposit which can be economically and legally extracted or produced at the time of the reserve determination;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:29.133PX; PADDING-RIGHT:10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&#147;economically&#148; implies that profitable extraction or production has been established or analytically demonstrated to be viable and justifiable under reasonable investment and market assumptions; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:29.133PX; PADDING-RIGHT:10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	while &#147;legally&#148; does not imply that all permits needed for mining and processing have been obtained or that other legal issues have been completely resolved, for a reserve to exist, there should be a reasonable certainty based on applicable laws and regulations that issuance of permits or resolution of legal issues can be accomplished in a timely manner.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT:10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Mineral reserves are categorized as follows on the basis of the degree of confidence in the estimate of the quantity and grade of the deposit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT:10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Under United States standards, proven or measured reserves are defined as reserves for which (a) quantity is computed from dimensions revealed in outcrops, trenches, workings or drill holes, grade and/or quality are computed from the results of detailed sampling and (b) the sites for inspection, sampling and measurement are spaced so closely and the geographic character is so well defined that size, shape, depth and mineral content of reserves are well established.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT:10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Under United States standards, probable reserves are defined as reserves for which quantity and grade and/or quality are computed from information similar to that of proven reserves (under United States standards), but the sites for inspection, sampling, and measurement are further apart or are otherwise less adequately spaced. The degree of assurance, although lower than that for proven mineral reserves, is high enough to assume continuity between points of observation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT:10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	AT THIS TIME, NONE OF OUR PROPERTIES CONTAIN ANY MINERAL RESERVE ESTIMATES IN ACCORDANCE WITH SEC GUIDE 7.
</B>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN=TOP WIDTH=126.533>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<B>
	Mineral Resource
</B>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN=TOP WIDTH=547.867>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT:10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	While the terms &#147;mineral resource,&#148; &#147;measured mineral resource,&#148; &#147;indicated mineral resource,&#148; and &#147;inferred mineral resource&#148; are recognized and required by Canadian regulations, they are not defined terms under standards in the United States. As such, information contained in this report concerning descriptions of mineralization and resources under Canadian standards may not be comparable to similar information made public by U.S. companies subject to the reporting and disclosure requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission. &#147;Indicated mineral resource&#148; and &#147;inferred mineral resource&#148; have a great amount of uncertainty as to their existence and a great uncertainty as to their economic and legal feasibility. It can not be assumed that all or any part of an &#147;indicated mineral resource&#148; or &#147;inferred mineral resource&#148; will ever be upgraded to a higher category. Investors are cautioned not to assume that any part or all of mineral deposits
	in these categories will ever be converted into reserves.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage8"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	8
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_3"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE:13.333PX" CELLSPACING=0>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN=TOP WIDTH=126.533>
<B>
	SAMREC Code
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN=TOP WIDTH=547.867>
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PX; PADDING-LEFT: 10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT: 10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The South African Mineral Resource Committee (SAMREC) under the auspices of the South African Institute of Mining and Metallurgy has developed a code for the reporting of Mineral Reserves and Resources (the &#147;SAMREC Code&#148;). &nbsp;The SAMREC Code contains definitions and standards comparable to definitions and standards which are recognized by NI 43-101.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PX; PADDING-LEFT: 10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT: 10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PX; PADDING-LEFT: 10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT: 10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	A &#145;Mineral Resource&#146; is a concentration or occurrence of material of economic interest in or on the earth&#146;s crust in such form, quality and quantity that there are reasonable and realistic prospects for eventual economic extraction. The location, quantity, grade, continuity and other geological characteristics of a Mineral Resource are known, or estimated from specific geological evidence, sampling and knowledge interpreted from an appropriately constrained and portrayed geological model. Mineral Resources are subdivided, and must be so reported, in order of increasing confidence in respect of geoscientific evidence, into Inferred, Indicated and Measured categories.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PX; PADDING-LEFT: 10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT: 10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PX; PADDING-LEFT: 10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT: 10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	An &#145;Inferred Mineral Resource&#146; is that part of a Mineral Resource
	for which tonnage, grade and mineral content can be estimated with a low level of confidence. It is inferred from geological evidence and sampling and assumed but not verified geological and/or grade continuity. It is based on information gathered through appropriate techniques from locations such as outcrops, trenches, pits, workings and drill holes that may be limited or of uncertain quality and reliability. &nbsp;An Inferred Mineral Resource has a lower level of confidence than that applying to an Indicated Mineral Resource.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PX; PADDING-LEFT: 10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT: 10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PX; PADDING-LEFT: 10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT: 10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	An &#145;Indicated Mineral Resource&#146; is that part of a Mineral Resource
	for which tonnage, densities, shape, physical characteristics, grade and mineral content can be estimated with a reasonable level of confidence. It is based on exploration, sampling and testing information gathered through appropriate techniques from locations such as outcrops, trenches, pits, workings and drill holes. The locations are too widely or inappropriately spaced to confirm geological and/or grade continuity but are spaced closely enough for continuity to be assumed. &nbsp;An Indicated Mineral Resource has sufficient confidence for global mine design, mine planning, and/or economic studies.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PX; PADDING-LEFT: 10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT: 10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PX; PADDING-LEFT: 10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT: 10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	A &#145;Measured Mineral Resource&#146; is that part of a Mineral Resource
	for which tonnage, densities, shape, physical characteristics, grade and mineral content can be estimated with a high level of confidence. It is based on detailed and reliable exploration, sampling and testing information gathered through appropriate techniques from locations such as outcrops, trenches, pits, workings and drill holes. The locations are spaced closely enough to confirm geological and grade continuity. &nbsp;A Measured Mineral Resource has sufficient confidence for mine design, mine planning, production planning, and/or detailed economic studies.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PX; PADDING-LEFT: 10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT: 10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PX; PADDING-LEFT: 10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT: 10.467PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Canadian Securities Administrators have added the SAMREC Code as an acceptable foreign code for reporting of mineral reserves and mineral resources. &nbsp;As a result issuers incorporated in Canada but with properties outside of Canada would also be able to report on mineral reserve and mineral resource categories as set out in NI 43-101 under SAMREC Code. &nbsp;The definition of a mineral reserve or a mineral resource under CIM standards or SAMREC Code are identical in effect, and hence no reconciliation is required for such instances where SAMREC Code has been properly applied.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN: 0PX; PADDING-LEFT: 10.2PX; PADDING-RIGHT: 10.467PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING:0PX; WIDTH:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:13.333PX; COLOR:#000000">

</P>

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<B>
	Glossary
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Except as otherwise identified, the following terms, when used herein, shall have the following meanings:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&#147;2PGE plus gold&#148; refers to platinum and palladium plus gold. These elements are assayed for separately but commonly occur together in the same mineralization in the South African context.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&#147;3 PGE plus gold&#148; refers to platinum, palladium, rhodium and gold. These elements are assayed for separately but commonly occur together in the same mineralization in the South African context and are commonly quoted as a basket for the overall grade assessment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;Common Stock&#148;
</B>
	refers to the common shares in the capital of PTM.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;Company Act&#148;
</B>
	refers to the
<I>
	Company Act
</I>
	(British Columbia). &nbsp;On March 30, 2004, the
<I>
	Company Act
</I>
	(British Columbia) was replaced by the
<I>
	Business Corporations Act
</I>
	(British Columbia).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;PTM&#148;
</B>
	refers to Platinum Group Metals Ltd.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;PTM-RSA&#148;
</B>
	refers to our wholly owned subsidiary incorporated under the laws of the Republic of South Africa under the name Platinum Group Metals (RSA) (Proprietary) Limited.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;RSA&#148;
</B>
	is an abbreviation for Republic of South Africa.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;TSX&#148;
</B>
	refers to the Toronto Stock Exchange.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;TSX-V&#148;
</B>
	refers to the TSX Venture Exchange.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;ZAR&#148;
</B>
	or &#147;R&#148; are both used is an abbreviation for South African Rand.
</P>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC65804430">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC66840866">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC66841023">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC66841182">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC95277941">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC95278096">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC95278273">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC95278406">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC95278445">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC97613461">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC98285493">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC98298042">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC127645438">
</A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage10"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	10
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<B>
	Glossary of Technical Terms
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;anomalous&#148;
</B>
	refers to a sample or location that either (i) the concentration of an element(s) or (ii) geophysical measurement is significantly different from the average background values in the area.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;anorthosite&#148;
</B>
	is a rock comprised of largely feldspar minerals and minor mafic iron-magnesium minerals.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;assay&#148;
</B>
	is an analysis to determine the quantity of one or more elemental components.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;Au&#148;
</B>
	refers to gold.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM_OLE_LINK15">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM_OLE_LINK16">
</A>
	BIC&#148;
</B>
	is an abbreviation for the Bushveld Igneous Complex in South Africa, the source of most of the world&#146;s platinum and is a significant producer of palladium and other platinum group metals (PGM&#146;s) as well as chrome. A layered suite of rocks that was once molten.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;cm&#148;
</B>
	is an abbreviation for centimetres.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;Cu&#148;
</B>
	refers to copper.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;critical zone&#148;
</B>
	a zone of geology known to contain mineralized layers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;exploration stage&#148;
</B>
	refers to the stage where a company is engaged in the search for minerals deposits (reserves) which are not in either the development or production stage.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;fault&#148;
</B>
	is a fracture or break in a rock across which there has been displacement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;gabbro&#148;
</B>
	is an intrusive rock comprised of a mixture of mafic minerals and feldspars.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;grade&#148;
</B>
	is the concentration of an ore metal in a rock sample, given either as weight percent for base metals (ie, Cu, Zu, Pb) or in grams per tonne (g/t) or ounces per short ton (oz/t) for precious or platinum group metals.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;g/t&#148;
</B>
	refers to grams per tonne.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;h&#148;
</B>
	is an abbreviation for hectare.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;hectare&#148;
</B>
	is an area totaling 10,000 square metres or 100 metres by 100 metres.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;intrusive&#148;
</B>
	is a rock mass formed below earth&#146;s surface from molten magma, which was intruded into a pre-existing rock mass and cooled to solid.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;km&#148;
</B>
	is an abbreviation for kilometre.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;m&#148;
</B>
	is an abbreviation for metres.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;mafic&#148;
</B>
	is a rock type consisting of predominantly iron and magnesium silicate minerals with little quartz or feldspar minerals.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;mineralization&#148;
</B>
	refers to minerals of value occurring in rocks.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_4"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;Mt&#148;
</B>
	is an abbreviation for million tonnes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;Ni&#148;
</B>
	is an abbreviation for nickel.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;NSR&#148;
</B>
	is an abbreviation for net smelter royalty.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="eolPage11"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	11
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;outcrop&#148;
</B>
	refers to an exposure of rock at the earth&#146;s surface.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;overburden&#148;
</B>
	is any material covering or obscuring rocks from view.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;pegmatoidal&#148;
</B>
	coarse grained when cooled from molten.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;Pd&#148;
</B>
	refers to palladium.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;PGE&#148;
</B>
	refers to mineralization containing platinum group elements, ie. platinum and palladium.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;PGM&#148;
</B>
	refers to platinum group metals, ie. platinum and palladium.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;Pt&#148;
</B>
	refers to platinum.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:6.667PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:6.667PX">
	&#147;Prill split&#148; - &nbsp;provides the breakdown of the estimated amounts of each of the platinum group elements (primarily platinum, palladium, rhodium and gold) that occur together in the mineralized reefs of layers&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;pyroxenite&#148;
</B>
	refers to a relatively uncommon dark-coloured rock consisting chiefly of pyroxene; pyroxene is a type of rock containing sodium, calcium, magnesium, iron, titanium and aluminum combined with oxygen.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;quartz&#148;
</B>
	is a common rock-forming mineral (SiO
<SUB>
	2
</SUB>
	)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;Rh&#148;
</B>
	refers to rhodium, a platinum metal. &nbsp;Rhodium shares some of the notable properties of platinum, including its resistance to corrosion, its hardness and ductility. Wherever there is platinum in the earth, there is rhodium as well. In fact, most rhodium is extracted from a sludge that remains after platinum is removed from the ore. A high percentage of rhodium is also found in certain nickel deposits in Canada.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;transvaal&#148;
</B>
	layer below the Bushveld Complex, sedimentary rocks
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	&#147;ultramafic&#148;
</B>
	refers to types of rock containing relatively high proportions of the heavier elements such as magnesium, iron, calcium and sodium; these rocks are usually dark in color and have relatively high specific gravities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC65804431">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC66840867">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC66841024">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC66841183">
</A>

</A>

</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC95278407">
</A>

</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC97613462">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC98285494">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC98298043">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC127645439">
</A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>

	12

<EFX_KEY_INFORMATION>
<A NAME="FIS_KEY_INFORMATION"></A>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:18.667PX; MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN BOLD; FONT-SIZE:16PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN BOLD">
<B>
	Item 3 &#150; Key Information
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC507527305">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC507527526">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC507531597">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC517420438">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC9352953">
</A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:13.333PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:3.333PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Selected Financial Data
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our selected financial data for the fiscal years ended August 31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 are derived from our consolidated financial statements which have been audited by Deloitte &amp; Touche LLP as indicated in their independent auditors&#146; report which is included elsewhere in this Annual Report. &nbsp;The selected financial data set forth for the years ended August 31, 2003 and 2002 are derived from our audited consolidated financial statements for such periods which are not included herein.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The selected financial data should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and notes thereto as well as the information appearing under the heading &#147;Item 5 &#150; Operating and Financial Review and Prospects.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have not declared any dividends since incorporation and do not anticipate doing so in the foreseeable future. &nbsp;Our present policy is to retain future earnings for use in our operations and the expansion of our business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>

</A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<B>
<I>
<U>
	Summary of Financial Data
</U>
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our financial statements and the table set forth below have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in Canada (&#147;Canadian GAAP&#148;), which differ in certain respects from those principles that we would have followed had our consolidated financial statements been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (&#147;U.S. GAAP&#148;). &nbsp;The major differences between Canadian GAAP and U.S. GAAP that would affect the measurement of our financial position, loss or cash flows are set forth in Note 15 to the accompanying consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>

	There are 56,206,247 shares of Common Stock issued and outstanding as of the date of this Form 20-F Annual Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
<U>
	Foreign Exchange Rates
</U>
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	All dollar amounts set forth in this report are in Canadian dollars, except where otherwise indicated. &nbsp;The following tables set forth, for the five most recent financial years, (i) the average rate (the &#147;Average Rate&#148;) of exchange for the Canadian dollar, expressed in U.S. dollars, calculated by using the average of the exchange rates on the last day for which data is available for each month during such periods; and (ii) the high and low exchange rate during the previous six months, in each case based on the noon buying rate in New York City for cable transfers in Canadian dollars as certified for customs purposes by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:13.333PX">
	The Average Rate is set out for each of the periods indicated in the table below.
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE:13.333PX" CELLSPACING=0>
<TR>
<TD WIDTH=137.4>
</TD>

</TD>

<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC152340766">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC152560770">
</A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:13.333PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:3.333PX">
<B>
<I>
	Risk Factors
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	An investment in our Common Stock entails certain risk factors, which should be considered carefully. &nbsp;The following is a brief discussion of those distinctive or special characteristics of our operations and industry that may have a material impact on, or constitute risk factors in respect of, our future financial performance.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our Common Stock should be considered a highly speculative investment and investors should carefully consider all of the information disclosed in this Annual Report prior to making an investment in our Common Stock. In addition to the other information presented in this Annual Report, the following risk factors should be given special consideration when evaluating an investment in our securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<I>
	General.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Resource exploration and development is a speculative business, characterized by a number of significant risks including, among other things, unprofitable efforts resulting not only from the failure to discover mineral deposits but also from finding mineral deposits, which, though present, are insufficient in quantity and quality to return a profit from production.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage15"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	15
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<I>
	Our business is subject to exploration and development risks.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	All of our properties are in the exploration stage and no known reserves have been discovered on such properties. At this stage, favourable drilling results, estimates and studies are subject to a number of risks, including:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:72PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	-
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:72PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	the limited amount of drilling and testing completed to date;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:72PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	-
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:72PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	the preliminary nature of any operating and capital cost estimates;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:72PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	-
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:72PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	the difficulties inherent in scaling up operations and achieving expected metallurgical recoveries; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:72PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	-
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:72PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	the likelihood of cost estimates increasing in the future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;There is no certainty that the expenditures to be made by us or by our joint venture partners in the exploration of the properties described herein will result in discoveries of precious metals in commercial quantities or that any of our properties will be developed. Most exploration projects do not result in the discovery of precious metals and no assurance can be given that any particular level of recovery of precious metals will in fact be realized or that any identified resource will ever qualify as a commercially mineable (or viable) resource which can be legally and economically exploited. Estimates of reserves, mineral deposits and production costs can also be affected by such factors as environmental permit regulations and requirements, weather, environmental factors, unforeseen technical difficulties, unusual or unexpected geological formations and work interruptions. In addition, the grade of precious metals ultimately discovered may differ from that indicated by drilling results. There can be no assurance that precious metals recovered in small-scale tests will be duplicated in large-scale tests under on-site conditions or in production scale.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<I>
	Our business may be affected by political and economic instability in South Africa.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our activities in South Africa are subject to risks common to operations in the mining industry in general, as well as certain political and economic uncertainties related specifically to operating in South Africa. &nbsp;South Africa has recently undergone significant change in its government since the free elections in 1994. &nbsp;At present, Mining Legislation in South Africa is undergoing change. &nbsp;The new Mineral Resources and Petroleum Development Act became law on May 1, 2004. &nbsp;The regulation and operation of this new law is still being implemented. &nbsp;In association with the new Act, the Mining Charter sets out a target of 26% ownership and participation in the mineral industry by &#147;Historically Disadvantaged Persons&#148; within ten years, but the mechanisms to fully affect this objective are still evolving. &nbsp;Accordingly, all laws may be considered relatively new, resulting in risks related to the possible misinterpretation of new laws, unilateral modification of mining or exploration rights, operating restrictions, increased taxes, environmental regulation, mine safety and other risks arising out of new sovereignty over mining, any or all of which could have an adverse affect on our business. &nbsp;Our operations in general may also be affected in varying degrees by political and economic instability, terrorism, crime, extreme fluctuations in currency exchange rates and inflation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC52539500">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC65804439">
</A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	We are subject to the risk of fluctuations in the relative values of the Canadian dollar as compared to the South African Rand and the U.S. dollar.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We may be adversely or favorably affected by foreign currency fluctuations. &nbsp;We are primarily funded through equity investments denominated in Canadian dollars; however several of our options to acquire properties in the Republic of South Africa may result in option payments denominated in South African Rand or in U.S. dollars. &nbsp;Our exploration and development programs to be conducted in South Africa will also be funded in South African Rand. &nbsp;Fluctuations in the exchange rate between the Canadian dollar as compared to the South African Rand and U.S. dollar may have an adverse or favorable affect on us.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	Our properties are subject to title risks.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have investigated title to all of our mineral properties and, to the best of our knowledge, title to all of our properties and properties in which we have the right to acquire or earn an interest are in good standing. &nbsp;However, our properties may be subject to prior unregistered agreements or transfers and title may be affected by undetected defects. &nbsp;These defects could adversely affect our title to such properties or delay or increase the cost of the development of such properties.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our properties in Canada may also be subject to aboriginal rights that may be claimed on Crown properties or other types of tenure with respect to which mineral rights have been conferred. &nbsp;We are not aware of any aboriginal land claims having been asserted or any legal actions relating to native issues having been instituted with respect to any of the mineral properties in
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage16"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	16
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Canada in which we have an interest. &nbsp;We are aware of the mutual benefits afforded by co-operative relationships with indigenous people in conducting exploration activity and we are supportive of measures established to achieve such co-operation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage17"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	17
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	South African foreign exchange controls may limit repatriation of profits.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Loan capital or equity capital may be introduced into South Africa through a formal system of Exchange Control. &nbsp;Proceeds from the sale of assets in South Africa owned by a non-resident are remittable to the non-resident. &nbsp;Approved loan capital is generally remittable to a non-resident company from business profits. &nbsp;Dividends declared by a non-listed South African company are remittable to non-resident stockholders. &nbsp;However, there can be no assurance that restrictions on repatriation of earnings from the Republic of South Africa will not be imposed in the future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<I>
	The mineral exploration industry is extremely competitive.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The resource industry is intensely competitive in all of its phases, and we compete with many companies possessing greater financial resources and technical facilities. &nbsp;Competition could adversely affect our ability to acquire suitable new producing properties or exploration prospects in the future. &nbsp;Competition could also affect our ability to raise financing to fund the exploration and development of our properties or to hire and retain qualified personnel.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	Judgments based upon the civil liability provisions of the United States federal securities laws may be difficult to enforce.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The ability of investors to enforce judgments of United States courts based upon the civil liability provisions of the United States federal securities laws against our company and our directors and officers may be limited due to the fact that a majority of these persons reside outside of the United States and, in respect of our directors and officers, their assets are located outside the United States. &nbsp;There is uncertainty as to whether Canadian courts would: &nbsp;(i) enforce judgments of United States courts obtained against our company or our directors and officers predicated upon the civil liability provisions of the United States federal securities laws, or (ii) entertain original actions brought in Canadian courts against our company or such persons predicated upon the federal securities laws of the United States, as such laws may conflict with Canadian laws. &nbsp;In Canada, civil rights are within the legislative jurisdiction of the Provinces and Territories. &nbsp;The Province of British Columbia, in which our company and all of our directors and officers are resident, does not have laws for the reciprocal enforcement of judgments of United States courts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	Our stock is a penny stock. &nbsp;Trading of our stock may be restricted by the SEC&#146;s penny stock regulations and the NASD&#146;s sales practice requirements, which may limit a stockholder&#146;s ability to buy and sell our stock.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our stock is a penny stock. &nbsp;The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted Rule 15g-9 which generally defines &#147;penny stock&#148; to be any equity security that has a market price (as defined) less than US $5.00 per share or an exercise price of less than US $5.00 per share, subject to certain exceptions. &nbsp;Our securities are covered by the penny stock rules, which impose additional sales practice requirements on broker-dealers who sell to persons other than established customers and &#147;accredited investors&#148;. &nbsp;The term &#147;accredited investor&#148; refers generally to institutions with assets in excess of US $5,000,000 or individuals with a net worth in excess of US $1,000,000 or annual income exceeding US $200,000 or US $300,000 jointly with their spouse. &nbsp;The penny stock rules require a broker-dealer, prior to a transaction in a penny stock not otherwise exempt from the rules, to deliver a standardized risk disclosure document in a form prepared by the SEC which provides information about penny stocks and the nature and level of risks in the penny stock market. &nbsp;The broker-dealer also must provide the customer with current bid and offer quotations for the penny stock, the compensation of the broker-dealer and its salesperson in the transaction and monthly account statements showing the market value of each penny stock held in the customer&#146;s account. &nbsp;The bid and offer quotations, and the broker-dealer and salesperson compensation information, must be given to the customer orally or in writing prior to effecting the transaction and must be given to the customer in writing before or with the customer&#146;s confirmation. &nbsp;In addition, the penny stock rules require that prior to a transaction in a penny stock not otherwise exempt from these rules, the broker-dealer must make a special written determination that the penny stock is a suitable investment for the purchaser and receive the purchaser&#146;s written agreement to the transaction. &nbsp;These disclosure requirements may have the effect of reducing the level of trading activity in the secondary market for the stock that is subject to these penny stock rules. &nbsp;Consequently, these penny stock rules may affect the ability of broker-dealers to trade our securities. &nbsp;We believe that the penny stock rules discourage investor interest in and limit the marketability of our Common Stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage18"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	18
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In addition to the &#147;penny stock&#148; rules promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the NASD has adopted rules that require that in recommending an investment to a customer, a broker-dealer must have reasonable grounds for believing that the investment is suitable for that customer. &nbsp;Prior to recommending speculative low priced securities to their non-institutional customers, broker-dealers must make reasonable efforts to obtain information about the customer&#146;s financial status, tax status, investment objectives and other information. &nbsp;Under interpretations of these rules, the NASD believes that there is a high probability that speculative low priced securities will not be suitable for at least some customers. &nbsp;The NASD requirements make it more difficult for broker-dealers to recommend that their customers buy our Common Stock, which may limit your ability to buy and sell our stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	We are a Passive Foreign Investment Company for United State Federal Income Tax Purposes which may have consequences for U.S. investors.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We believe that our company is a passive foreign investment company (&#147;PFIC&#148;) for United States Federal income tax purposes because we earn 75% or more of our gross income from passive sources. &nbsp;As a result, a United States holder of our Common Stock could be subject to increased tax liability, possibly including an interest charge, upon the sale or other disposition of the United States holders&#146; Common Stock or upon receipt of &#147;excess distributions,&#148; unless such holder of common shares elect to be taxed currently on his or her pro rata portion of our income, whether or not the income was distributed in the form of dividends or otherwise. &nbsp;The election requires certain conditions be met such as filing on or before the due date, as extended, for filing the stockholder&#146;s income tax return for the first taxable year to which the election will apply. &nbsp;Otherwise, the election may only partially apply. &nbsp;Further, the elections will increase the administrative and regulatory burden on us. &nbsp;See &#147;Passive Foreign Investment Company&#148; on page 65.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	Metal prices affect the success of our business.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The mining industry in general is intensely competitive and there is no assurance that, even if commercial quantities of mineral resources are developed, a profitable market will exist for the sale of same. &nbsp;Factors beyond our control may affect the marketability of any minerals discovered. &nbsp;No assurance may be given that metal prices will remain stable. &nbsp;Significant price fluctuations over short periods of time may be generated by numerous factors beyond our control, including domestic and international economic and political trends, expectations of inflation, currency exchange fluctuations, interest rates, global or regional consumption patterns, speculative activities and increased production due to improved mining and production methods. &nbsp;The effect of these factors on the price of minerals and therefore the economic viability of any of our exploration projects cannot accurately be predicted. &nbsp;As we are in the exploration stage, the above factors have had no material impact on present operations or income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	We will need additional financing.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	At August 31, 2006, we had working capital of $8,602,700 (2005 - $1,396,283). &nbsp;Subsequent to the year end, we received aggregate proceeds of $3,736,665 upon the exercise of 2,433,194 share purchase warrants at a price of $1.50 per share, 50,000 stock options at a price of $1.10 per share and 31,875 stock options at a price of $1.00 per share. &nbsp;We believe that these funds will be sufficient to cover general and administrative costs and fund obligations and proposed exploration programs and engineering studies on our properties to August 31, 2007. &nbsp;We have limited financial resources and no sources of operating cash flow. &nbsp;There can be no assurance that additional funding will be available to us for further exploration and development of our properties beyond the current programs. &nbsp;In the past, we have relied on sales of equity securities to meet our cash requirements. &nbsp;There can be no assurance that future operations will provide cash flow sufficient to satisfy operational requirements and cash commitments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Should additional properties be acquired or programs be undertaken, we will require additional funding. &nbsp;The exploration and development of our properties depends upon our ability to obtain financing through any or all of the joint venturing of projects, debt financing, equity financing or other means. &nbsp;There can be no assurance that we will be successful in obtaining any required financing now or in the future. &nbsp;Failure to obtain additional financing on a timely basis could result in delay or indefinite postponement of further exploration and development of our mineral properties, with the possible loss of such properties, or the inability to acquire any additional properties.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">

<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage19"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	19
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<I>
	Our operations are subject to environmental and government regulation.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Environmental legislation on a global basis is evolving in a manner that will ensure stricter standards and enforcement, increased fines and penalties for non-compliance, more stringent environmental assessment of proposed development and a higher level of responsibility for companies and their officers, directors and employees. There can be no assurance that future changes to environmental legislation in Canada or South Africa will not adversely affect our operations. Environmental hazards may exist on our properties which are unknown at present and which have been caused by previous or existing owners or operators. Furthermore, future compliance with environmental reclamation, closure and other requirements may involve significant costs and other liabilities. In particular, our operations and exploration activities are subject to Canadian and South African national and provincial laws and regulations governing protection of the environment. Such laws are continually changing and, in general, are becoming more restrictive.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Amendments to current laws, regulations and permits governing operations and activities of mining companies, or more stringent implementation thereof, could have a material adverse impact on us and cause increases in capital expenditures or production costs or reduction in levels of production at producing properties or require abandonment or delays in development of new mining properties.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have not made any material expenditure for environmental compliance to date. &nbsp;However, there can be no assurance that environmental laws will not give rise to significant financial obligations in the future and such obligations could have a material adverse affect on our financial performance.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	The occurrence of events for which we are not insured or for which our insurance is inadequate may reduce or eliminate any future profitability and result in increasing costs and a decline in the value of our securities.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In the course of exploration, development and production of mineral properties, certain risks, and in particular, unexpected or unusual geological operating conditions including rock bursts, cave-ins, fire, flooding and earthquakes may occur. &nbsp;It is not always possible to fully insure against such risks as a result of high premiums or other reasons. &nbsp;Should such liabilities arise, they could reduce or eliminate any future profitability and result in increasing costs and a decline in the value of our securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	We have limited experience with development-stage mining operations.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have limited experience in placing mineral properties into production, and our ability to do so will be dependent upon using the services of appropriately experienced personnel or entering into agreements with other major resource companies that can provide such expertise. &nbsp;There can be no assurance that we will have available the necessary expertise when and if we place our mineral properties into production.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	We have a history of losses and we anticipate continuing to incur losses for the foreseeable future.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have a history of losses including net losses of $3,853,273 in the year ended August 31, 2006; $3,795,648 in the year ended August 31, 2005; and $2,242,627 in the year ended August 31, 2004. &nbsp;At August 31, 2006, we had an accumulated deficit of $15,410,804 (2005 - $11,557,531). &nbsp;We anticipate continuing to incur losses for the foreseeable future until we can successfully place one or more of our properties into commercial production on a profitable basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	We have a lack of cash flow, which may affect our ability to continue as a going concern.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We are an exploration company with a history of losses and no history of revenues from our operations. &nbsp;None of our properties are in production or are expected to be developed in the near future, if at all. &nbsp;During the year ended August 31, 2006, we had a loss of $3,853,273 (2005 - $3,795,648) and used $2,356,261 (2005 - $2,591,906) in cash for operating activities and $6,522,431 (2005 - $5,549,707) in cash for investing activities. &nbsp;Historically, the only source of funds available to us has been through the sale of our equity securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage20"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	20
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The auditors&#146; report on our August 31, 2006 annual consolidated financial statements includes additional comments which indicate that the financial statements are affected by conditions and events that cast doubt on our ability to continue as a going concern. &nbsp;The financial statements do not include any adjustments that might result from the outcome of this uncertainty. &nbsp;Our continuing operations and the recoverability of the amounts capitalized for mineral properties in our consolidated financial statements, prepared in accordance with Canadian GAAP, is dependent upon our ability in the future to achieve profitable operations and, in the meantime, to obtain the necessary financing to meet our obligations and repay our liabilities arising from normal business operations when they become due. External financing, predominately by the issuance of equity to the public, will be sought to finance our operations; however, there is no assurance that sufficient funds will be raised.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	We are required to contribute our share of exploration costs to maintain our interests in certain properties.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We may, in the future, be unable to meet our share of costs incurred under agreements to which we are a party and we may as a result be subject to loss or dilution of our rights to acquire interests in the properties subject to such agreements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<I>
	None of our properties contain any known reserves.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	All of our properties are in the exploration stage meaning that we have not determined whether any such property contains mineral reserves that are economically recoverable. &nbsp;Failure to discover economically recoverable reserves will require us to write-off costs capitalized in our Canadian GAAP financial statements, which at August 31, 2006 totaled $16,660,885 (2005 - $12,091,549).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<I>
	We depend on our key management employees.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our development to date has depended, and in the future will continue to depend, on the efforts of our key management figures: &nbsp;R. Michael Jones, our Chairman, President, CEO and director; Frank R. Hallam, our Chief Financial Officer and director; and John Gould, the Managing Director of PTM-RSA. &nbsp;The loss of any of our key management figures could have a material adverse effect on us. &nbsp;With the exception of John Gould, we have entered into contracts with the named directors, officers and employees. &nbsp;See &#147;Item 6 &#150; Directors, Senior Management and Employees&#148; and &#147;Item 7 &#150; Major Shareholders and Related Party Transactions&#148;. &nbsp;We do not maintain key man insurance on any of our management.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	Our directors may be associated with other mineral resource companies.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Certain of our officers and directors may become associated with other natural resource companies that acquire interests in mineral properties. &nbsp;R. Michael Jones, our Chairman, President, Chief Executive Officer and director is also a director of Jerico Explorations Inc., a public company with a mineral exploration property in Arizona, a director of West Timmins Mining Inc., a public company with mineral exploration properties in Canada and Mexico, and a director of MAG Silver Corp., a public company with silver properties in Mexico. &nbsp;Frank Hallam, our Chief Financial Officer and director, is also a senior officer of MAG Silver Corp., a director of Jerico Explorations Inc., a senior officer of Callinan Mines Ltd., a base metals exploration company with projects in Manitoba and British Columbia and a director and senior officer of West Timmins Mining Inc. &nbsp;Eric Carlson, director, is also a director of MAG Silver Corp. and a director of West Timmins Mining Inc. &nbsp;Any conflicts, which may arise, will be dealt with as disclosed below.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Such associations may give rise to conflicts of interest from time to time. &nbsp;Our directors are required by law to act honestly and in good faith with a view to the best interests of our company and to disclose any interest, which they may have in any project or opportunity of our company. &nbsp;If a subject involving a conflict of interest arises at a meeting of the board of directors, any director in a conflict will disclose his interest and abstain from voting on such matter. In determining whether or not our company will participate in any project or opportunity, the directors will primarily consider the degree of risk to which our company may be exposed and our financial position at that time.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">

<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage21"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	21
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	We have outstanding stock options and share purchase warrants which, if exercised, could cause dilution to existing stockholders.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	At November 17, 2006, we had 3,402,875 stock options issued and outstanding with a weighted average exercise price of $1.00 per share and 4,750,000 share purchase warrants issued and outstanding with a weighted average exercise price of $1.96 per share. &nbsp;Stock options and share purchase warrants are likely to be exercised when the market price of our Common Stock exceeds the exercise price of such stock options or share purchase warrants. &nbsp;The exercise of such stock options or share purchase warrants and the subsequent resale of such Common Stock in the public market could adversely affect the prevailing market price and our ability to raise equity capital in the future at a time and price which we deem appropriate. &nbsp;We may also enter into commitments in the future which would require the issuance of additional Common Stock and we may grant additional share purchase warrants and stock options. &nbsp;Any share issuances from our treasury will result in immediate dilution to existing stockholders.
</P>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC52539501">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC54064766">
</A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	Our share price has been volatile in recent years.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In recent years, the securities markets in the United States and Canada have experienced a high level of price and volume volatility, and the market price of many companies, particularly those considered exploration or development stage companies, have experienced wide fluctuations in price which have not necessarily been related to the operating performance, underlying asset values or prospects of such companies. &nbsp;In particular, the per share price of our Common Stock on the TSX and TSX-V fluctuated from a high of $2.37 to a low of $1.27 and on the NASD OTC Bulletin Board Service from a high of US $2.09 to a low of US $1.05 within the twelve month period preceding the date of this Annual Report. There can be no assurance that continual fluctuations in price will not occur.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<I>
	We do not expect to pay dividends.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have not paid any dividends since incorporation and we have no plans to pay dividends for some time. &nbsp;Our directors will determine if and when dividends should be declared and paid in the future based on our financial position at the relevant time. &nbsp;All of the shares of Common Stock are entitled to an equal share of any dividends declared and paid.
</P>
</EFX_KEY_INFORMATION>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>

<EFX_COMPANY_INFORMATION>
<A NAME="FIS_COMPANY_INFORMATION"></A>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:18.667PX; MARGIN:0PX; FONT-SIZE:16PX">
<B>
	Item 4 &#150; Information on the Company
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<I>
	Introduction
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our company is a British Columbia corporation incorporated on February 18, 2002 by an order of the Supreme Court of British Columbia approving an amalgamation between Platinum Group Metals Ltd. and New Millennium Metals Corporation. &nbsp;Our company was later transitioned on February 22, 2005 under the
<I>
	Business Corporations Act
</I>
	(British Columbia). &nbsp;On February 22, 2005, our stockholders passed a special resolution to amend the authorized share capital from 1,000,000,000 shares of Common Stock without par value to an unlimited number of shares of Common Stock without par value, to remove the pre-existing company provisions and to adopt new articles.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our head office is located at Suite 328 &#150; 550 Burrard Street, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, V6C 2B5, telephone (604) 899-5450. &nbsp;The address for service and our registered and records office is Gowlings Lafleur Henderson, LLP, Suite 2300, 1055 Dunsmuir Street, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, V7X 1J1. Our website is www.platinumgroupmetals.net. &nbsp;We are a reporting issuer in British Columbia, Alberta, Ontario and Quebec and our Common Stock currently trades on the TSX under the symbol &#147;PTM&#148; and on the NASD OTC Bulletin Board Service under the symbol &#147;PTMQF&#148;.
</P>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC9352961">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC9353189">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:4PX">
<B>
<I>
	Business Overview
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our business is conducted primarily in South Africa, and to a lesser extent, in Ontario, Canada. &nbsp;As at the date hereof, our WBJV Project in South Africa constitutes our only material property. &nbsp;None of our properties contain any mineral reserve estimates in accordance with SEC Guide 7.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage22"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	22
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Exploration on our South Africa and Ontario properties are not affected by seasonal changes although in Ontario, heavy equipment may or may not be moved over the soft ground for approximately six weeks in the spring during thaw.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	To conduct our exploration, we are dependent on sub-contractors for certain geological services, drilling equipment and supplies. &nbsp;These are generally available but vary in price and immediacy of availability subject to demand.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We do not earn any revenues from operations; however, we do earn interest from cash deposits. &nbsp;For the three years ended August 31, 2006, we earned interest and other income of $235,236 (Fiscal 2006), $218,373 (Fiscal 2005), and $430,106 (Fiscal 2004). &nbsp;We have financed our operations principally through the sale of equity securities. &nbsp;While we believe there is sufficient capital and liquidity to finance current operations until August 31, 2007, nevertheless, our ability to continue operations is dependent on our ability to obtain additional financing. &nbsp;See &#147;Item 3 - Key Information &#150; Risk Factors.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The material effects of government regulations on our business are identified in &#147;Item 3 - Key Information &#150; Risk Factors.&#148;
</P>

<I>
	Property, Plants and Equipment
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our executive offices are located in rented premises of approximately 5,500 square feet at Suite 328, 550 Burrard Street, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, V6C 1T2, telephone (604) 899-5450. &nbsp;We began occupying this facility on October 1, 2004 on a three-year lease and it is considered adequate for current needs. &nbsp;PTM-RSA occupies rented premises of approximately 5,000 square feet at Technology House, Greenacres Office Park, Victory Park, Johannesburg 2193, telephone +27-11-782-2186. &nbsp;PTM-RSA began occupying this facility on July 1, 2006 on a three-year lease. &nbsp;The current annual combined obligation for both rented premises, including lease obligations for office equipment, is approximately $149,372.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have no significant plant or equipment for our operations. &nbsp;Equipment used for exploration or drilling is rented or contracted as needed.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<B>
	Western Bushveld Joint Venture Project, Republic of South Africa
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC127645451">
</A>

</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC152340686">

</A>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:17.333PX; MARGIN:0PX; FONT-SIZE:14.667PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
<I>
	Property Description, Location and Acquisition
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<U>
	Area, Extent and Location of Project
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Western Bushveld Joint Venture (&#147;WBJV&#148;) Project is located on the southwestern limb of the Bushveld Igneous Complex, some 50 km northwest of the North West Province town of Rustenburg (see Figure 1). &nbsp;The project area consists of farms Frischgewaagd 96JQ, Portion 7 (a portion of Portion 2), Portions 15 and 16 and Elandsfontein 102JQ, Portion 12 of Elandsfontein 102JQ and Mineral Area 2 (a portion of Mineral Area 1) (see Figure 2) situated in the southeastern corner of the larger joint venture area. &nbsp;Rustenburg is situated about 120 km northwest of Johannesburg within the Republic of South Africa.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The access to the WBJV Project is by tar road. Water for exploration is supplied locally by well site and from the regional water utility and power is supplied from the regional electric utility company via an existing grid. These facilities will need to be upgraded for potential mine operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The total joint-venture area includes our properties, Elandsfontein 102JQ and Onderstepoort 98JQ, but also certain portions of Elandsfontein 102JQ, Frischgewaagd 96JQ and Koedoesfontein 94JQ contributed by our joint-venture partner Rustenburg Platinum Mines Limited (&#147;RPM&#148;), a wholly owned subsidiary of Anglo American Platinum Corporation Limited (&#147;Anglo
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage23"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	23
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Platinum&#148;). &nbsp;These properties are centered on Longitude 27
<SUP>
	0
</SUP>
	00&#146;00&#148;(E) and Latitude 25
<SUP>
	0
</SUP>
	20&#146;00&#146;&#146;(S) and the mineral rights cover an extent of approximately 67km
<SUP>
	2
</SUP>
	.
</P>
