<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC152560777">
</A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:13.333PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:3.333PX">
<B>
<I>
	Critical Accounting Policies
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our accounting policies are set out in Note 2 and 15 of the accompanying consolidated financial statements. &nbsp;In addition to these consolidated financial statements, the following accounting policies are also detailed below:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Effective September&nbsp;1, 2004, the Company adopted the amended recommendations of the Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants (&#147;CICA&#148;) Handbook Section 3870,
<I>
	Stock-based Compensation and Other Stock-based Payments
</I>
	. &nbsp;Under the amended standards of this section, the fair value of all stock-based awards granted are estimated using the Black-Scholes model and are recorded in operations over their vesting periods. &nbsp;The compensation cost related to stock options granted after September&nbsp;1, 2004 is recorded in operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Previously, the Company provided note disclosure of pro forma net earnings and pro forma earnings per share as if the fair value based method had been used to account for share purchase options granted to employees, directors and officers after September&nbsp;1, 2002. The amended recommendations have been applied retroactively from September&nbsp;1, 2002 without restatement of prior periods. &nbsp;As a result, as of September&nbsp;1, 2004, the deficit was increased by $318,000, contributed surplus was increased by $304,977, and share capital was increased by $13,023 for share purchase options granted in prior years and exercised in Fiscal 2005.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	There are two policies that, due to the nature of the mining business, are more significant to our financial results. &nbsp;These policies relate to the capitalizing of mineral exploration expenditures and the use of estimates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Under Canadian GAAP, we deferred all costs relating to the acquisition and exploration of our mineral properties. &nbsp;Any revenues received from such properties are credited against the costs of the property. &nbsp;When commercial production commences on any of our properties, any previously capitalized costs would be charged to operations using a unit-of-
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage40"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	40
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	production method. We regularly review deferred exploration costs to assess their recoverability and when the carrying value of a property exceeds the estimated net recoverable amount, provision is made for impairment in value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Management reviews the carrying value, for accounting purposes, of mineral rights and deferred exploration costs on at least a quarterly basis for evidence of impairment. &nbsp;This review is generally made with reference to the project economics, including the timing of the exploration work, work programs proposed, exploration results achieved by us and others in the related area of interest and any changes in the status of the property. &nbsp;When the results of this review indicate that a condition of impairment exists, we estimate the net recoverable amount of the deferred exploration costs and related mining rights by reference to the potential for success of further exploration activity and the likely proceeds to be received from a sale or assignment of rights. &nbsp;When the carrying values of mineral rights or deferred exploration costs are estimated to exceed their net recoverable amounts, a provision is made for the decline in the value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	When assessing for evidence of impairment, we also refer to the other factors relevant for companies in the extractive industries. &nbsp;These factors include unfavourable changes in the property (including disputes as to title), inability to access the site, environmental restrictions on exploration or development and political instability in the region in which the property is located. &nbsp;Furthermore, we conclude an event of impairment has occurred when any of the following conditions exist:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-24PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	a.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	our work program on a property has significantly changed such that previously identified resource targets or work programs are no longer being pursued;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-24PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	b.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	exploration results are not promising and no more work is being planned in the foreseeable future; or
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-24PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	c.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	remaining lease terms are insufficient to conduct necessary exploration work.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The existence of uncertainties during the exploration stage and the lack of definitive empirical evidence with respect to the feasibility of successful commercial development of any exploration property do create measurement uncertainty concerning the calculation of the amount of impairment. &nbsp;We rely on our own or independent estimates of further geological prospects of a particular property and also consider the likely proceeds from a sale or assignment of the rights.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The latter will often be indicated by offers that our company or others have received for exploration rights in the same or similar geological area. &nbsp;In many cases, the identified condition of impairment will result in a determination that no further exploration activity be performed and the amount of the write-down is the entire carrying value of the interest.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Under U.S. GAAP, we currently expense all costs relating to the exploration of our mineral properties. &nbsp;At such time as a final bankable feasibility indicates that a property has a commercially mineable deposit, development costs for that property would be capitalized. &nbsp;When commercial production commences on any such property, any previously capitalized costs would be charged to operations using a unit-of-production method.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our financial statements are based on the selection and application of significant accounting policies, some of which require management to make estimates and assumptions. &nbsp;Estimates are based on historical experience and on our future expectations that are believed to be reasonable; the combination of these factors forms the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. &nbsp;Actual results are likely to differ from our current estimates and those differences may be material.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During the fiscal year ended August 31, 2006 the net loss under U.S. GAAP was $8,537,460 (2005 - $8,112,593; 2004- $4,675,466), which was $4,684,187 (2005 - $4,316,945; 2004 - $2,432,839) higher than the net loss recognized under Canadian GAAP. &nbsp;Of this difference, $5,474,479 (2005 - $5,309,860; 2004 - $2,711,412) relates to the fact that under U.S. GAAP, mineral property acquisition and exploration costs are expensed as incurred rather than capitalized until management has determined that an impairment exists in the carrying value of the property, as they are under Canadian GAAP. &nbsp;An amount of $Nil (2005 - ($1,136,055); 2004 &#150; $Nil) relates to the cost of stock based compensation for employees and directors which is an expense under Canadian GAAP, but was treated only as a disclosure item by our company under SFAS 123 in the USA for fiscal years prior to August 31, 2006. &nbsp;In 2006 there was no difference in the treatment between Canadian and U.S. GAAP. &nbsp;Also, an amount of $5,506 would be recognized as a recovery for U.S. GAAP in 2006 versus an expense of $660,574 in 2005 (2004 &#150; expense of $190,242) due to the difference in the accounting for income taxes on the issuance of flow-through shares for Canadian GAAP versus U.S. GAAP. &nbsp;Finally, a stock option expense of $50,200 would be
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>

</P>

</A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:13.333PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:3.333PX">
<B>
<I>
	Overview
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our main objective is to acquire mineral properties, finance their exploration and, if warranted, develop, and bring them into commercial production either directly or by way of joint venture or option agreements or through a combination of the foregoing. &nbsp;We are aiming to develop our properties to a stage where they could be exploited at a profit. &nbsp;At that stage, our operations would to some extent be dependent upon the world market price of any minerals mined.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have deferred mineral property acquisition costs and exploration expenditures of $16,660,885 at August 31, 2006 compared to $12,091,549 at August 31, 2005 and $5,995,550 at August 31, 2004. &nbsp;The recoverability of these amounts is dependent upon the existence of economically recoverable reserves, securing and maintaining title and beneficial interest in our properties, our ability to obtain the necessary financing to meet our obligations under various agreements and the completion of the development of our properties, any future profitable production, or alternatively, upon our ability to dispose of our interests on an advantageous basis. &nbsp;We have incurred losses since inception of $15,410,804 and have working capital of $8,602,700 at August 31, 2006; in light of these facts, there is some doubt as to our ability to continue as a going concern.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC9353098">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC9353326">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC9353544">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC34011157">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC34011935">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC34012412">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC34794482">
</A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Future write-downs of properties are dependent on many factors, including general and specific assessments of mineral resources, the likelihood of increasing or decreasing the resources, land costs, estimates of future mineral prices, potential extraction methods and costs, the likelihood of positive or negative changes to the environment, taxation, labor and capital costs. &nbsp;It is not possible to assess the monetary impact of these factors at the current stage of our properties. &nbsp;The dollar amounts shown as mineral properties and deferred exploration expenditures are direct costs of acquiring, maintaining and exploring properties, including costs of structures and equipment employed on the properties and allocations of administrative management salaries based on time spent and directly related to specific properties. &nbsp;These amounts do not necessarily reflect present or future values.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Additional financing will be required for further exploration and development of our properties. &nbsp;Although we have been successful in the past in raising funds, there is no assurance that we will be able to raise the necessary capital to meet our funding obligations in the future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have not been required to make any material expenditure for environmental compliance to date. &nbsp;Our operations may in the future be affected from time to time in varying degrees by changes in the environmental regulations. &nbsp;Both the likelihood of new regulations and their overall effect on us are not predictable. &nbsp;See &#147;Item 3 &#150; Key Information, Risk Factors.&#148;
</P>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC65804510">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC66840949">

</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC95278169">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC97613480">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC98285513">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC98298067">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC127645455">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC151737950">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC151738090">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC152336807">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC152340107">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC152340324">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC152340690">

<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC152340775">

<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC152560779">
</A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:13.333PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:3.333PX">
<B>
<I>
	Operating Results
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We are not adversely affected by inflation at the present time, and are not likely to be in the near future. &nbsp;However, there is no guarantee that this will remain to be the case. &nbsp;High or extreme rates of inflation would adversely affect our business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We may be adversely or favorably affected by foreign currency fluctuations. &nbsp;In the normal course of our business, we enter into transactions for the purchase of supplies and services denominated in South African Rand. &nbsp;We also have cash and certain liabilities denominated in South African Rand. &nbsp;As a result, we are subject to foreign exchange risk from fluctuations in foreign exchange rates. &nbsp;In the past year, the South African Rand has fallen in value against the Canadian dollar by approximately 14%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	Year Ended August 31, 2006 Compared to the Year Ended August 31, 2005
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have been very active in 2006, primarily on the WBJV in South Africa. &nbsp;The scale and tenor of the WBJV makes that project an investment focus for us, and as a result our other projects have been less active during the fiscal year. &nbsp;During the year, we incurred a loss of $3,853,273 (2005 - $3,795,648). Before a non-cash charge for stock based compensation of $110,176 (2005 - $1,283,289) and for mineral property costs written of $1,174,325 (2005 &#150; $974,294), general and administrative expenses totaled $2,808,715 (2005 - $2,466,085). &nbsp;Interest, other income and recoveries amounted to $235,236
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage42"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	42
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(2005 - $218,373). &nbsp;The loss for the year in 2005 was reduced by a provision for future income tax recoveries of $793,000, while in 2006 there was no such provision.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	As operator of the WBJV, we have engaged a multi-discipline team of independent engineers, which commenced detailed pre-feasibility study work in early January 2006. The pre-feasibility study will consider the opportunities presented as the result of further drilling up until September of 2006. &nbsp;Approximately 40% of the WBJV surface area has been investigated in drilling to date. &nbsp;To November 2006, we completed approximately 160 boreholes for 72,000 metres of drilling on the WBJV. &nbsp;During calendar 2006, we completed three independent resource calculations for the WBJV, the most recent one being published on September 21, 2006. &nbsp;As of November 2006, we have deployed five drilling rigs for further drilling of the WBJV, primarily in the Project 2 and Project 3 areas of the property.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	From October 2004 to April 2006, we operated and funded a required exploration program in the amount of ZAR 35 million (at August 31, 2005 approx. US$5.4 million; C$6.44 million). &nbsp;The WBJV partners are now required to fund their portion of further expenditures pro-rata based upon their working interest in the joint venture. &nbsp;In March 2006, the WBJV partners approved a 2006 cash budget for the WBJV totaling ZAR 29,712,200 (approx. Cdn $4.59 million at August 31, 2006). &nbsp;Later, in September 2006 this budget was increased to a cumulative total of ZAR 76,393,208 (approx. Cdn. $11.75 million at September 2006). &nbsp;Each party is required to fund their pro-rata share of the approved budget by way of several separate cash calls. &nbsp;To November 17, 2006, both our company and Anglo Platinum have funded ZAR 21,370,075 towards the approved budget and Africa Wide has funded ZAR 3,200,000. &nbsp;Of the $2,126,584 in accounts payable at August 31, 2006, an amount of $1,850,000 was incurred on behalf of the WBJV.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In May 2005, we reached agreement to purchase all surface and mineral rights to the Elandsfontein 102 JQ property, now a component property in the WBJV, in exchange for ZAR 7.0 million. &nbsp;On September 16, 2005, we made a final payment of ZAR 2.8 million to close the purchase.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Mineral property acquisition costs deferred during the year totaled $300,928 (2005 - $1,815,434). Of this amount $93,367 (2005 &#150; 1,512,446) related to WBJV properties. &nbsp;Exploration and development costs deferred in the year totaled $5,474,479 (2005 - $5,309,860). Of that amount $4,998,447 (2005 - $3,023,125) was incurred on the WBJV. &nbsp;A further $448,610 (2005 - $126,859) was incurred on other South African properties while $27,422 (2005 - $1,079,938) was incurred on Canadian properties
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Cost recoveries on Canadian mineral properties during the year amounted to Nil (2005 - $55,000). &nbsp;During the year $1,174,325 (2005 - $974,294) in deferred costs relating to mineral properties were written off. &nbsp;An amount of $964,847 (2005 - $958,844) was written off for Ontario projects while the balance of $209,478 (2005 - $15,450) related to South African write offs. &nbsp;See details of the WBJV and mineral properties in Notes 5 and 6 of our audited financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	Year Ended August 31, 2005 Compared to the Year Ended August 31, 2004
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During the year ended August 31, 2005, we incurred a loss of $3,795,648 (2004 - $2,242,627). Before a non-cash charge for stock based compensation of $1,283,289 (2004 - $92,881), general and administrative expenses totaled $2,466,085 (2004 - $1,723,248). Interest, other income and recoveries amounted to $218,373 (2004 - $430,106). The loss for the year includes mineral property write down expenses of $974,294 (2004 - $1,044,542) and is reduced by a provision for future income tax recoveries of $793,000 (2004 - $278,000).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On October 27, 2004, we announced the formation of the WBJV with Anglo Platinum and Africa Wide. Work commenced immediately thereafter on the WBJV project and the rate of work accelerated during the year. Activities consisted of research and data review, prospecting, mapping, engineering and drilling of the project area. &nbsp;In August of 2005, we completed an engineering review, a statement of inferred resources, and Preliminary Assessment of the first planned project on the WBJV in compliance with National Instrument 43-101. We were also active with an exploration program on the War Springs project in South Africa, consisting of diamond drilling, geophysical surveys and ground prospecting.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During the year, we executed a settlement and purchase agreement for both the surface rights and mineral rights to the Elandsfontein 102 JQ property, now a component property in the WBJV. &nbsp;The total purchase price became ZAR 7.0 million (approx. C$1.3 million), after a discount of ZAR 200,000 for early settlement. &nbsp;Prior to August 31, 2005, we paid out ZAR 4.2 million in payments and in September 2005 paid a final payment of ZAR 2.8 million to complete the transaction.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage43"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	43
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Other work during the year included the completion, assessment and analysis of drilling and geophysical results from the Seagull project and the Lakemount project, both located in Ontario, Canada.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have increased our general level of activity in the past two years in South Africa. Activities in Canada have been reduced, as the more advanced nature of the WBJV project has caused it to become our investment focus. We still actively review many potential property acquisitions in the normal course of business. We have also increased marketing efforts in order to raise our profile in the capital markets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Mineral property acquisition costs deferred during the year totaled $1,815,434 (2004 - $515,777), most of which was for South African property acquisition costs and payments. Exploration and development costs deferred in the year totaled $5,309,860 (2004 - $2,711,412). Of that amount $1,079,938 (2004 - $1,330,643) was incurred on our Canadian properties. An amount of $4,229,922 (2004 - $1,380,769) was incurred on our South African properties.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Cost recoveries on Canadian mineral properties during the year amounted to $55,000 (2004 - $78,750). During the year $974,294 (2004 - $1,044,542) in deferred costs relating to mineral properties were written off. An amount of $958,844 (2004 - $1,018,252) was written off for Ontario projects while the balance of $15,450 (2004 - $26,290) related to South African write offs. See details of the WBJV and mineral properties in Notes 5 and 6 of our audited financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC95278019">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM__TOC95278170">
</A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	Year Ended August 31, 2004 Compared to the Year Ended August 31, 2003
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During the year, we incurred a loss of $2,242,627 (2003 &#150; $1,748,993). &nbsp;Included were mineral property write down expenses of $1,044,542 (2003 &#150; $815,714) and a provision for future income tax recoveries of $278,000 (2003 &#150; $212,400).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During the year, we actively reviewed many potential property acquisitions and increased efforts to raise our profile and liquidity in the capital markets. &nbsp;Due to these factors, we incurred generally higher costs in 2004 over prior years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Net general and administration expenses in 2004 were $1,381,432 (2003 - $905,248) after accounting for interest and other income of $430,106 (2003 - $177,068). &nbsp;During the years 2002, 2003 and 2004, our company grew substantially through the amalgamation with New Millennium Metals Corporation and expansion into the Republic of South Africa. &nbsp;General and administrative expenses are generally higher as a result of this growth. &nbsp;During 2004, we opened and staffed a permanent office in Johannesburg and commenced active exploration. &nbsp;The costs described above include corporate finance fees of $100,000 (2003 - $nil); management and consulting fees of $322,996 (2003 &#150; $232,201); office and miscellaneous expenses of $106,306 (2003 - $ 64,263); professional fees of $130,383 (2003 - $143,357); salaries and benefits of $404,936 (2003 - $167,115); shareholder relations expense of $38,090 (2003 - $159,532); travel expenses of $231,507 (2003 - $50,364); and promotion expenses of $126,464 (2003 - $42,560). &nbsp;Stock compensation expense, a non-cash item, amounted to $92,881 in 2004 (2003 - $42,051). &nbsp;An amount of $6,500 (2002 - $29,875) in expense relates to Part XII.6 tax applied by the Canadian Federal government on unspent flow-through funds from the previous year. &nbsp;An amount of $4,591 (2003 &#150; $41,508) was expensed for new property investigations during the period. Interest and other income for the year totaled $430,106 (2003 - $177,068).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Acquisition costs deferred during the current year totaled $515,777 (2003 &#150; $459,809). &nbsp;Exploration and development costs deferred in 2004 totaled $2,711,412 (2003 &#150; $1,296,469). &nbsp;Of that amount $1,330,643 (2003 - $483,889) was incurred on our Canadian properties. &nbsp;An amount of $1,380,769 (2003 - $812,580) was incurred on our South African properties.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Cost recoveries before adjustments on mineral properties during the year amounted to $78,750 (2003 &#150; $(40,335)). &nbsp;In 2003, recoveries amounted to $141,539, but after recognizing an adjustment for $181,874 in work converted to shares by Wheaton River Minerals Ltd. (known as Goldcorp Inc. since 2005 merger), the net amount for the year was a charge of $40,335. &nbsp;During the year $1,044,542 (2003 &#150; $815,714) in deferred costs relating to mineral properties were written off. &nbsp;An amount of $1,018,252 (2003 - $510,830) was written off for Ontario projects while the balance of $26,290 (2003 - $304,884) related to South African write offs. &nbsp;On our Agnew Lake Property located west of Sudbury, Ontario, joint venture partners Pacific Northwest Capital and Kaymin Resources Limited, (a subsidiary of Anglo Platinum) spent approximately $2.5 million on the property.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>

	44
</P>

<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During 2004, we spent $302,573 (2003 - $288,320) on exploration work on the Shelby Lake and Lac des Iles, Ontario properties. &nbsp;Work consisted mostly of drilling, mapping and geochemistry.
</P>

<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:13.333PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:3.333PX">
<B>
<I>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our working capital is a direct result of the excess of funds raised from the sale of equity shares and the receipt of property payments over expenditures into acquisition and exploration costs as well as administrative expenses. &nbsp;The working capital balance at the end of the following periods were: &nbsp;August 31, 2006: $8,602,700; August 31, 2005: &nbsp;$1,396,283; August 31, 2004 - $2,364,360. &nbsp;Fluctuations in working capital stem from timing differences between when money is raised from equity issues and when expenditures are committed on exploration.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Cash and cash equivalents at August 31, 2006 totaled $10,066,801 compared to $2,750,461 at August 31, 2005 and $2,423,176 at August 31, 2004. &nbsp;The cash and cash equivalents are attributable primarily to the issue of share capital. &nbsp;Aside from cash and cash equivalents, we had no material unused sources of liquid assets at August 31, 2006, 2005 or 2004.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During Fiscal 2006, we issued a total of 10,532,547 shares (2005 - 8,571,216 shares) of Common Stock of which 10,507,547 shares (2005 - 8,546,216 shares) were issued for cash proceeds of $16,197,710 (2005 - $8,482,291), plus $47,669 (2005 - $13,023), which came from contributed surplus. A further 25,000 shares (2005 &#150; 25,000) of Common Stock were issued for mineral properties for a value of $40,000 (2005 - $28,000). &nbsp;Cash proceeds were to be spent on mineral property acquisitions, exploration and development as well as for general working capital purposes. The primary use of cash during the year was for acquisition and exploration expenditures, being approximately $6,423,839 (2005 - $5,395,698), management fees and expenses of $367,891 (2005 - $326,167) and other general and administrative expenses of $2,440,824 (2004 - $2,139,918) as calculated before applying a non-cash charge of $110,176 (2005 - $1,283,289) for stock compensation expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During Fiscal 2005, we issued a total of 8,571,216 shares (2004 - 6,756,148 shares) of Common Stock of which 8,546,216 shares (2004 - 6,745,239 shares) were issued for cash proceeds of $8,482,291 (2004 - $5,981,397), and $13,023 came from contributed surplus. A further 25,000 shares (2004 - 10,909 shares) were issued for mineral properties for a value of $28,000 (2004 - $3,600). Cash proceeds were to be spent on mineral property acquisitions, exploration and development as well as for general working capital purposes. The primary use of cash during the year was for acquisition and exploration expenditures, being approximately $5,395,698 (2004 - $3,178,589), management fees and expenses of $326,167 (2004 - $322,996) and other general and administrative expenses of $2,139,918 (2004 - $1,400,252) as calculated before applying a non-cash charge of $1,283,289 (2004 - $92,881) for stock compensation expense. &nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During Fiscal 2004, we issued a total of 6,756,148 shares of Common Stock of which 6,745,239 shares were issued for cash proceeds of $5,981,397. A further 10,909 shares were issued for mineral properties for a value of $3,600. Cash proceeds are to be spent on mineral property acquisitions, exploration and development as well as for general working capital purposes. &nbsp;Our primary source of capital has been from the sale of equity. &nbsp;The primary use of cash during the year was for acquisition and exploration expenditures, being approximately $3,178,589 (2003 - $1,178,638), management fees and expenses of $322,996 (2003 - $232,201) and other general and administrative expenses of $1,488,542 (2003 - $850,115).
</P>

<B>
<I>

</I>
</B>

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The following table discloses our contractual obligations for optional mineral property acquisition payments, optional exploration work and committed lease obligations for office rent and equipment. We have no long term debt or loan obligations. &nbsp;Under the terms of several of our mineral property option and purchase agreements, we are required to make certain scheduled acquisition payments and incur minimum annual exploration expenditures as summarized in the table below in order to preserve our interests in the related mineral properties. &nbsp;In the event we are unable or unwilling to make these payments, it is likely that we would forfeit our rights to acquire the related properties.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:13.333PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:3.333PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Directors and Senior Management
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The following table sets out certain information concerning our directors and executive officers. &nbsp;Each director holds office until our next annual general meeting or until his successor is elected or appointed, unless his office is earlier vacated in accordance with our Articles, or with the provisions of the
<I>
	Business Corporations Act
</I>
	(British Columbia)
<I>
</I>
	(the &#147;BCA&#148;). &nbsp;The officers are appointed at the pleasure of the board of directors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>

	Notes:
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-13.333PX; PADDING-LEFT:54PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(1)

	Member of the Audit Committee
</P>
</EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-13.333PX; PADDING-LEFT:54PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(2)
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:54PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Member of Compensation Committee
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	No director and/or executive officer has been the subject of any order, judgment, or decree of any governmental agency or administrator or of any court or competent jurisdiction, revoking or suspending for cause any license, permit or other authority of such person or of any corporation of which he is a director and/or executive officer, to engage in the securities business or in the sale of a particular security or temporarily or permanently restraining or enjoining any such person or any corporation of which he is an officer or director from engaging in or continuing any conduct, practice, or employment in connection&nbsp;with the purchase or sale of securities, or convicting such person of any felony or misdemeanor involving a security or any aspect of the securities business or of theft or of any felony.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	While our directors and executive officers are involved in other business ventures and do not spend full time on the affairs of our company, we believe that each devotes as much time to the affairs of our company as are required to satisfactorily carry out their duty.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	There are no family relationships between any two or more directors or executive officers. &nbsp;There are no arrangements or understandings between any of the directors or executive officers, major stockholders, customers, suppliers or others pursuant to which any person referred to above was selected as a director or executive officer.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
<U>
	R. Michael Jones, P.Eng, Chairman, President, CEO and Director
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Mr. Jones holds a Bachelor of Applied Science (Geological Engineering) from the University of Toronto (1985). &nbsp;Mr. Jones&#146; experience includes mineral exploration in Canada, the U.S.A., Guyana, and Honduras for base and precious metals since 1985 and includes the formation and management, as a senior executive, of mineral exploration, development and mining companies. &nbsp;Mr. Jones has been a senior officer of public mineral exploration and development companies since 1987. &nbsp;He was a founder of Glimmer Resources Inc. that was involved in the discovery and exploration of the Glimmer Gold mine near Timmins, Ontario. &nbsp;He was the President of Cathedral Gold Corporation, a producing gold mining company from 1992 to 1997, and from 1997 to 1999, he was a Vice President of Aber Resources, a mining company that is developing a diamond mine. Mr. Jones has not explored for PGE deposits prior to his work with our company. &nbsp;Currently Mr. Jones spends approximately 90% of his time on the affairs of our company. &nbsp;His responsibilities include management of our business and the final review of exploration programs and budgets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Mr. Jones is also a director of Jerico Explorations Inc., a public company with a mineral exploration property in Arizona, a director MAG Silver Corp., a public company with silver properties in Mexico, and West Timmins Mining Inc., a public company with gold properties in Canada and Mexico.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage47"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	47
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<B>
<U>
	Frank R. Hallam, BBA, CA, Chief Financial Officer and Director
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Mr. Hallam received his Bachelor of Business Administration from Simon Fraser University in 1990. &nbsp;Prior to 1989 Mr. Hallam worked in the mineral exploration industry in British Columbia and Alberta. &nbsp;From 1989 to 1994 Mr. Hallam was a Senior Associate with Coopers &amp; Lybrand (now PriceWaterhouseCoopers) where he specialized as an auditor in the mining practice. &nbsp;Mr. Hallam qualified as a Chartered Accountant in 1993. &nbsp;Mr. Hallam left public practice in 1994 and since then has served at the senior management level with several publicly listed resource companies. &nbsp;His experience includes mining finance and mineral exploration and operations in Canada, the U.S.A. and several countries in East and South Africa. &nbsp;Prior to his involvement with our company Mr. Hallam was involved in the formation and operation of exploration joint ventures with Newmont Mining Corporation, Barrick Gold Corporation and Johannesburg Consolidated Investment Company Limited. &nbsp;Mr. Hallam currently devotes 90% of his time on the affairs of our company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Mr. Hallam is also a senior officer of MAG Silver Corp., a director of Jerico Explorations Inc., a senior officer of Callinan Mines Ltd., a base metals exploration company with projects in Manitoba and British Columbia and a director and senior officer of West Timmins Mining Inc.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
<U>
	Barry Smee, PhD., PGeo, Secretary and Director
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Dr. Smee received his PhD from the University of New Brunswick in 1982 and received his B.Sc. from the University of Alberta in 1969. &nbsp;He holds the professional designation of P.Geo from APEGBC. &nbsp;Since 1990, Dr. Smee has been the President of Smee &amp; Associates, offering consulting, geological and geochemical services to the mining industry. &nbsp;Dr. Smee has been a director of Colony Pacific Explorations Ltd., a public company listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange, since 1997 and has acted as a director of several other public companies including Getchell Resources, Leeward Capital, X-Cal Resources and Cross Lake Minerals. &nbsp;Currently Dr. Smee spends approximately 10% of his time on the affairs of our company. &nbsp;His responsibilities include a role as an independent director and a consulting role as a geochemist as required. &nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<B>
<U>
	Iain McLean, BSc Eng (ARSM), MBA, MIMM. CEng, Director and Consultant of Corporate Development
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Mr. McLean received his M.B.A. from Harvard Business School in 1986 and received his B.Sc (Eng.) in Mining from the Imperial College of Science and Technology (London, England) in 1978. &nbsp;Mr. McLean holds the professional designations of C.Eng. and MIMM from the Institute of Mining and Metallurgy. &nbsp;Mr. McLean has acted as the Chief Operating Officer of several private high technology companies since 1995 and was the Vice President of Operations at Ballard Power Systems
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	from 1993 to 1995. &nbsp;Currently Mr. McLean spends approximately 10% of his time on the affairs of our company. &nbsp;His responsibilities include assisting the President in all aspects of his work and focusing on strategic partnerships and new businesses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
<U>
	Eric Carlson, Director
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Mr. Carlson has over 17 years of real estate investment, development, and management experience. Mr. Carlson has been President and Chief Executive Officer of Anthem Properties Corp. (&#147;Anthem&#148;) since July 1994. Anthem is an investment group that specializes in the acquisition and management of Class B retail, multi-family residential and office properties in high growth markets in Canada and the United States. Mr. Carlson has also been President and a director of Kruger Capital Corp. since December 1992. Mr. Carlson is a Chartered Accountant and holds a Bachelor of Commerce degree from the University of British Columbia. &nbsp;Currently Mr. Carlson spends approximately 5% of his time on the affairs of our company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Mr. Carlson is also a director of MAG Silver Corp. and West Timmins Mining Inc.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
<U>
	John Gould, Managing Director of PTM-RSA
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Mr.
<B>
</B>
	Gould is a senior mining executive with over 21 years of experience working for companies in South Africa such as Goldfields of South Africa, Johannesburg Consolidated Investment Company Limited and Harmony Gold Mining Company Ltd. Mr. Gould served as a production geologist for Rustenburg Platinum Mines&#146; Amandelbult Section on the Western Bushveld Complex where he gained extensive shaft-sinking experience. &nbsp;Mr. Gould served as Mine Manager of a Witwatersrand Gold Mine for Harmony and then moved to the New Business Division where he was involved in target generation, optimization of contiguous properties, and mergers and acquisitions.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Effective August 1, 2006, we entered into a consulting agreement (the &#147;Jones Agreement&#148;) with R. Michael Jones, our President, Chief Executive Officer and director pursuant to which Mr. Jones is paid a fee of $645 per day to manage our day-to-day operations for an indefinite term. &nbsp;We may terminate the Jones Agreement on notice without cause upon payment of three months&#146; typical consulting fees and provision of benefits made available to our officers from time to time on terms determined by the board of directors for the earlier of three months or until Mr. Jones obtains comparable benefits from another source. &nbsp;
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM_OLE_LINK8">
</A>
<A NAME="PLATINUM20FA052107_HTM_OLE_LINK9">
</A>
	Mr. Jones may terminate the Jones Agreement at any time by providing 90 days&#146; written notice to us. &nbsp;The Jones Agreement includes a provision whereby Mr. Jones shall have 60 days from the date of a change of control of our company to elect in writing whether or not he wishes to terminate the Jones Agreement, after which time he shall be deemed to have elected not to do so. &nbsp;If Mr. Jones elects to terminate the Jones Agreement, then he shall give written notice of his election to us and the Jones Agreement shall terminate 30 days from the date of such notice. &nbsp;Jones shall then, from the date of termination, be entitled to receive from us in one lump sum the equivalent of one year&#146;s compensation, defined in the Jones Agreement as $165,000.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Effective August 1, 2006, we entered into an employment agreement (the &#147;Hallam Agreement&#148;) with Frank R. Hallam, our Chief Financial Officer and director pursuant to which Mr. Hallam is paid a salary of $12,100 per month to manage our day-to-day financial operations for an indefinite term. &nbsp;We may terminate summarily and without notice, or payment in lieu of notice, severance payments, benefits, damages or any sums whatsoever, in the event that there is just cause for termination of Mr. Hallam&#146;s employment. We may terminate the Hallam Agreement on notice without cause upon payment to him at termination of three months&#146; base salary and provision of benefits made available to our officers at the discretion of the board of directors. Mr. Hallam may terminate the Hallam Agreement at any time by providing 90 days&#146; written notice to us. The Hallam Agreement includes a provision whereby Mr. Hallam shall have 60 days from the date of a change of control of our company to elect in writing whether or not he wishes to terminate the Hallam Agreement, after which time he shall be deemed to have elected not to do so. &nbsp;If Mr. Hallam elects to terminate the Hallam Agreement, then he shall give written
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage49"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	49
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	notice of his election to us and the Hallam Agreement shall terminate 30 days from the date of such notice. &nbsp;Mr. Hallam shall then, from the date of termination, be entitled to receive from us in one lump sum the equivalent of one year&#146;s compensation, defined in the Hallam Agreement as $145,000.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have no pension plan or other arrangements for non-cash compensation to our directors except the grant of stock options.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:13.333PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:3.333PX">
<B>
<I>
	Board Practices
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The board of directors presently consists of five directors. &nbsp;Each director was elected at the annual general meeting of our stockholders held on January 10, 2006. &nbsp;Each director holds office until our next annual general meeting or until his successor is elected or appointed, unless his office is earlier vacated in accordance with our Articles, or with the provisions of the
<I>
	Business Corporations Act
</I>
	(British Columbia). &nbsp;See &#147;Directors and Senior Management&#148; for the dates on which our current directors were first elected or appointed.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have not entered into contracts providing for benefits to the directors upon termination of employment, other than those described above in &#147;Compensation&#148;.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<B>
<I>
	Board Committees
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT">
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPSMT">
	The Audit Committee and the Compensation Committee, being the only committees of the board, are composed of a majority of the members who are both outside and unrelated directors.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPS-BOLDMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPS-BOLDMT">
<B>
<I>
	The Audit Committee
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPSMT">
	The Audit Committee consists of three directors, Mr. Carlson, Mr. Smee and Mr. McLean, all of whom are considered independent and unrelated. The role of the Audit Committee is to assist the board in fulfilling their oversight responsibility to the stockholders, potential stockholders, the investment community and others relating to: (i) the integrity of our financial statements; (ii) the financial reporting process; (iii) the systems of internal accounting and financial controls; (iv) the performance of our internal audit function and independent auditors; (v) the independent auditor&#146;s qualifications and independence; and (vi) our compliance with ethics policies and legal and regulatory requirements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The principal responsibilities of the Audit Committee include reviewing annual and quarterly financial statements, ensuring that internal controls over accounting and financial systems are maintained and that accurate financial information is disseminated to stockholders, reviewing the results of internal and external audits and any change in accounting procedures or policies, evaluating the performance of our auditors, pre-approving all audit and non-audit services provided by the auditors and establishing the remuneration of the auditors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The following is the text of the current Charter for the Audit Committee as adopted by the board on January 11, 2005. Such Charter may be amended by the board in the future in light of evolving corporate governance standards.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPS-BOLDMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPS-BOLDMT">
<B>
<I>
	Overall Purpose / Objectives
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPSMT">
	The Audit Committee will assist the board of directors (the &#147;Board&#148;) in fulfilling its responsibilities. The Audit Committee will review the financial reporting process, the system of internal control and management of financial risks, the audit process, and our process for monitoring compliance with laws and regulations and its own code of business conduct. In performing its duties, the committee will maintain effective working relationships with the board of directors, management, and the external auditors and monitor the independence of those auditors. To perform his or her role effectively, each committee member will obtain an understanding of the responsibilities of committee membership as well as our business, operations and risks.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage50"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	50
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPS-BOLDMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPS-BOLDMT">
<B>
<I>
	Authority
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPSMT">
	The Board authorizes the Audit Committee, within the scope of its responsibilities, to seek any information it requires from any employee and from external parties, to obtain outside legal or professional advice and to ensure the attendance of our officers at meetings as appropriate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPS-BOLDMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPS-BOLDMT">
<B>
<I>
	Organization
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPSMT">
<U>
	Membership
</U>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Audit Committee will be comprised of at least three members, a majority of which are not officers or employees of our company, at least one of whom will have accounting or related financial management expertise.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The chairman of the Audit Committee will be nominated by the committee from time to time.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	A quorum for any meeting will be two members.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The secretary of the Audit Committee will be the Secretary of our company, or other such person as may be nominated by the Chairman of, and approved by, the Audit Committee.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<U>
	Attendance at Meetings
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Audit Committee may invite such other persons (e.g. the President or Chief Financial Officer) to its meetings, as it deems appropriate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Meetings shall be held not less than four times a year. Special meetings shall be convened as required. External auditors may convene a meeting of the Audit Committee if they consider that it is necessary.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The proceedings of all meetings will be minuted.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
<I>
	Roles and Responsibilities
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Audit Committee will:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(a)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Gain an understanding of whether internal control recommendations made by external auditors have been implemented by management.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(b)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Gain an understanding of the current areas of greatest financial risk and whether management is managing these effectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(c)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Review significant accounting and reporting issues, including recent professional and regulatory pronouncements, and understand their impact on the financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(d)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Review any legal matters which could significantly impact the financial statements as reported on by our counsel and meet with outside independent counsel whenever deemed appropriate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(e)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Review the annual and quarterly financial statements, including Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis with respect thereto, and all annual and interim earnings press releases, prior to public dissemination, including any certification, report, opinion or review rendered by the external auditors and determine whether they are complete and consistent with the information known to committee members; determine that the auditors are satisfied that the financial statements have been prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(f)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Pay particular attention to complex and/or unusual transactions such as those involving derivative instruments and consider the adequacy of disclosure thereof.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage51"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	51
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(g)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Focus on judgmental areas, for example those involving valuation of assets and liabilities and other commitments and contingencies.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(h)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Review audit issues related to our material associated and affiliated companies that may have a significant impact on our equity investment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(i)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Meet with management and the external auditors to review the annual financial statements and the results of the audit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(j)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Evaluate the fairness of the interim financial statements and related disclosures including the associated Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis, and obtain explanations from management on whether:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(i)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	actual financial results for the interim period varied significantly from budgeted or projected results;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(ii)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	generally accepted accounting principles have been consistently applied;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(iii)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	there are any actual or proposed changes in accounting or financial reporting practices; or
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(iv)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	there are any significant or unusual events or transactions which require disclosure and, if so, consider the adequacy of that disclosure.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(k)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Review the external auditors&#146; proposed audit scope and approach and ensure no unjustifiable restriction or limitations have been placed on the scope.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(l)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Review the performance of the external auditors and approve in advance provision of services other than auditing. &nbsp;Consider the independence of the external auditors, including reviewing the range of services provided in the context of all consulting services bought by our company. The Board authorizes the Chairman of the Audit Committee to approve any non-audit or additional audit work which the Chairman deems as necessary and to notify the other members of the Audit Committee of such non-audit or additional work.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(m)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Make recommendations to the Board regarding the reappointment of the external auditors and the compensation to be paid to the external auditor.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(n)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Review any significant disagreement among management and the external auditors in connection with the preparation of the financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(o)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Review and approve our hiring policies regarding partners, employers and former partners and employees of the present and former external auditors of our company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(p)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Establish a procedure for:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPSMT">
	(i)
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	the confidential, anonymous submission by our employees of concerns regarding questionable accounting or auditing matters; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(ii)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	the receipt, retention and treatment of complaints received by our company regarding accounting, internal accounting controls, or auditing matters.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(q)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Meet separately with the external auditors to discuss any matters that the committee or auditors believe should be discussed privately in the absence of management.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(r)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Endeavour to cause the receipt and discussion on a timely basis of any significant findings and recommendations made by the external auditors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(s)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Ensure that the Board is aware of matters which may significantly impact the financial condition or affairs of the business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<HR STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:9.6PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:9.6PX" NOSHADE SIZE=1.333>
<A NAME="eolPage52"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	52
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPSMT">
	(t)
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Perform other functions as requested by the full Board.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(u)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	If necessary, institute special investigations and, if appropriate, hire special counsel or experts to assist, and set the compensation to be paid to such special counsel or other experts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(v)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Review and recommend updates to the charter; receive approval of changes from the Board.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; TEXT-INDENT:-47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(w)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	With regard to our internal control procedures, the Audit Committee is responsible to:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(i)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	review the appropriateness and effectiveness of our policies and business practices which impact on our financial integrity, including those related to internal auditing, insurance, accounting, information services and systems and financial controls, management reporting and risk management; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(ii)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	review compliance under our business conduct and ethics policies and to periodically review these policies and recommend to the board changes which the Audit Committee may deem appropriate; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(iii)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	review any unresolved issues between management and the external auditors that could affect our financial reporting or internal controls; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(iv)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:94.533PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	periodically review our financial and auditing procedures and the extent to which recommendations made by the internal audit staff or by the external auditors have been implemented.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPS-BOLDMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPS-BOLDMT">
<B>
<I>
	The Compensation Committee
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPSMT">
	The Compensation Committee consists of two directors, Mr. McLean and Mr. Smee, both of whom are considered independent and unrelated. The role of the Compensation Committee is primarily to administer our Stock Option Plan and to determine the remuneration of executive officers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>

	Notes:
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-13.333PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX">
	(1)
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:48PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX">
	Includes beneficial, direct and indirect shareholdings.
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-13.333PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX">
	(2)
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:48PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX">
	Does not include stock options and other rights to purchase or acquire shares.
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-13.333PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX">
	(3)
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:48PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX">
	There are
	56,206,247 shares of Common Stock issued and outstanding as of the date of this Form 20-F Annual Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-13.333PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX">
	(4)
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:48PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX">
	Of these shares, 956,000 shares are held by 599143 B.C. Ltd., a company 50% owned by Mr. Jones and 50% owned by Mr. Jones&#146; wife.
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-13.333PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX">
	(5)
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.333PX; MARGIN:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:48PX; FONT-SIZE:10.667PX">
	Of these shares, 33,800 shares are held by Carmax Enterprises Corporation, a private company owned by Mr. Carlson.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We do not have a share purchase plan or dividend reinvestment plan; however we do have a stock option plan pursuant to which our company will, from time to time, grant individual stock options to our directors, officers, employees and consultants.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:TIMESNEWROMANPSMT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMESNEWROMANPSMT">
	We implemented the stock option plan (the &#147;Plan&#148;) on January 14, 2003. &nbsp;On January 10, 2006, our stockholders approved an amendment to the Plan increasing the maximum number of shares issuable pursuant to the Plan to 4,500,000 shares of Common Stock. &nbsp;The Plan is administered by the board of directors or such committee of the board as may be designated by the board (the &#147;Committee&#148;). Options may be granted pursuant to the Plan to our directors, officers, employees and consultants to purchase shares of Common Stock on such terms that the board or the Committee may determine, subject to the limitations of the plan and the rules of applicable regulatory authorities. The exercise price for options granted under the Plan may not be less than the closing price of the Common Stock on the TSX on the trading day immediately preceding the day on which the option is granted (provided that if there are no trades on such day then the last closing price within the preceding ten trading days will be used, and if there are no trades within such ten-day period, then the simple average of the bid and ask prices on the trading day immediately preceding the day of grant will be used), in each case less up to the maximum discount permitted by the TSX. &nbsp;Options under the Plan are non-assignable and are exercisable for a period of up to ten years from the date the option is granted, subject to earlier termination after certain events such as the optionee&#146;s cessation of service to our company or death.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table discloses the share purchase warrants outstanding to the aforementioned persons as of November 17, 2006:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:14.667PX; MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-RIGHT:34.8PX; FONT-SIZE:12PX" ALIGN=RIGHT>
	9.5%

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<I>
	Holders of Record in the United States
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:NORMAL; MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Based on our knowledge, after reasonable inquiry as of November 24, 2006, the most recent practicable date for conducting such search in the light of the time required for responses, the total number of shares of Common Stock held of record by 73 residents in the United States is 21,428,907 shares of Common Stock representing approximately 38.13% of the 56,206,247 shares of Common Stock then issued and outstanding. &nbsp;The foregoing is comprised of the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	1.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	According to the records of our registrar and transfer agent, Pacific Corporate Trust Company, there are 9,811,969 shares of Common Stock held of record by 18 residents of the United States, one of which is Cede &amp; Co. with a total of 6,063,641 shares of Common Stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-16PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	2.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We have ascertained that there are 6,425,068 shares of Common Stock held by one resident of the United States through CDS &amp; Co. in Canada.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
<BR>

<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">

	55

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
